data:
Anaphylaxis is highly likely if ONE of these criteria are met:
- Criteria 1: Acute onset of an illness (minutes to several hours) involving skin, mucosal tissue or both (generalized hives, pruritus or flushing, swollen lips-tongue-uvula) and at least 1 of the following: respiratory compromise or hypotension (or associated symptoms)
- Criteria 2: 2 or more of the following that occur rapidly (minutes to several hours) after exposure to a likely allergen for that patient: skin or mucosal symptoms, respiratory symptoms or signs, hypotension (or associated symptoms), gastrointestinal symptoms (abdominal pain, nausea or vomiting)
- Criteria 3: hypotension following minutes to several hours exposure to a known allergen for that patient: SBP less than 90 mmHg or reduced by 30% from baseline

For anaphylaxis, administration of adjunctive agents should not delay or substitute epinephrine administration if anaphylaxis is present. Role of adjunctive H1 and H2 antihistamines or steroids not certain in anaphylaxis. H1 antihistamines will relieve itching, angioedema, flushing, urticaria. Concurrent H2 antagonists may help reduce flushing or headache. Steroids may prevent protracted anaphylaxis and biphasic response
Continue to assess for recurrence of hives or pruritus, oral or facial edema, shortness of breath, wheezing, GI symptoms or hypotension
Notify treating provider for recurrent or worsening allergic reaction symptoms
Provide patient education for allergic reactions, prevention, diphenhydrAMINE and EPIPEN use
